name: 歐洲奇幻文學研究專題
description:
This course is designed to introduce to the students two types of speculative

literature: fantasy and sci-fi. The emphasis would be placed on the ambiguous dichotomy and dialectical ambiguity of two essential schools of thought: humanism and posthumanism. To better understand the speculative literature, we will have recourse to several contemporary theorists and/or thinkers, such as Cary Wolfe, Donna Haraway, Katherine Hayles, Bruno Latour, and Michel Serres. We will devote our discussion to the works of European si-fi/fantasy writers of eight countries. In an age of information technology where almost every kind of knowledge is on the Internet, speculative literature plays a crucial role to show not so much the restoration of a non-existent fantastic world, as the stimulation and evolution of culturally-modified fantasy and the making of fantasy in the posthumanist experiences.
goals: The constant questioning of the ambiguity of the speculative is the basic requirement for academic research.
The ability of communication is indeed the crucial component for human beings to understand the speculative.
The mode of philosophical and ethical inquiry is the way to develop capacities for independent judgment, critical thinking, and ethical reasoning.
The goal of this course is the ultimate concern of the other through the speculative mode of thinking

**課程簡介**

This course is designed to introduce to the students two types of speculative literature: fantasy and sci-fi. The emphasis would be placed on the ambiguous dichotomy and dialectical ambiguity of two essential schools of thought: humanism and posthumanism. To better understand the speculative literature, we will have recourse to several contemporary theorists and/or thinkers, such as Cary Wolfe, Donna Haraway, Katherine Hayles, Bruno Latour, and Michel Serres. We will devote our discussion to the works of European si-fi/fantasy writers of eight countries. In an age of information technology where almost every kind of knowledge is on the Internet, speculative literature plays a crucial role to show not so much the restoration of a non-existent fantastic world, as the stimulation and evolution of culturally-modified fantasy and the making of fantasy in the posthumanist experiences.
